meta.title: Eco-physiological processes underlying maize water use efficiency response to plant density under contrasting water regimes
meta.author: M Hernández D Hernández, C Alfonso, A Cerrudo, M Cambareri, A Della Maggiora, P Barbieri, M Echarte M Echarte, L Echarte

div.text: This study quantified maize (Zea mays L.) water use efficiency for grain yield (WUEg) in response to plant density under contrasting water regimes; and focused on relevant eco-physiologial processes underlying the responses of maize WUEg to plant density (i.e., the proportion of transpiration in the total water used, T/ET; and the crop growth rate during the critical period for kernel set, CGRcp). Maize crops were grown at Balcarce, Argentina during two seasons. Treatments included two water regimes (i.e., rainfed and irrigated) and three plant densities (4, 8 and 12 plants m -2 ). Measurements comprised (i) soil water content and iPAR during the whole growing season, (ii) shoot biomass around silking and (iii) grain yield and shoot biomass at physiological maturity. Crop ET was calculated by means of water balance and soil evaporation was measured with microlysimeters. The response of WUEg to increasing plant density from 4 to 8 or from 4 to 12 plants m -2 was influenced by seasonal water supply. Both seasonal ET and T/ET consistently increased with plant densities across contrasting water regimes. Although increments in T/ET partition were in accordance with increasing iPAR, they did not promote higher WUEg at low water supply. Grain yield increased with plant density, except in the driest environment where no response of either grain yield nor WUEg to plant density was detected. Our results showed that the response of CGRcp to plant density increments (i) depended on the water supply, and (ii) contributed to explain WUEg response to plant density under contrasting water supplies.

Maize grain yield can be expressed as a function of water use during the season (i.e., evapotranspiration, ET) and water use efficiency for grain yield (WUEg, i.e., the quotient between grain yield and ET; Viets, 1962;Howell, 2001). Large grain yield variability across years for rainfed crops were associated with water supply during the maize growing season (Nielsen et al., 2009;Calviño et al., 2003). Therefore, maximizing WUEg is a major target to cope with years with low water supply.

Increasing plant density is a management practice that has the potential of increasing WUEg: in non-water limited environments, higher plant densities promoted larger WUEg in maize (Yao and Shaw, 1964;Timmons et al., 1966;Lamm et al., 2009;Al-Kaisi and Yin, 2003), as well as in other crops (e.g., Echarte et al., 2020). Higher plant densities increase the interception of photosynthetically active radiation per unit area (iPAR; Tetio-Kagho and Gardner, 1988;Andrade et al., 1993;Andrade et al., 2002a). Larger iPAR, in particular during the critical period for kernel set (i.e. 30 days around silking; Tollenaar et al., 1992), are associated with higher grain yields explained by greater crop growth rates (CGRcp) which, in turn, increase kernel number per unit area (Andrade et al., 1999(Andrade et al., , 2002b)). In addition, higher canopy cover are associated with higher transpiration (T) and lower evaporation rates (E; i.e., loss of non-productive water; Ritchie, 1972;Villalobos and Fereres, 1990;Allen et al., 1998). Therefore, larger WUEg at higher plant densities could be the result of (i) an improved ET partition towards productive water use (i.e., higher T/ET ratio) during the growing season, and/or (ii) to greater crop growth capacity, specifically during the critical period for kernel set (i.e., CGRcp).

High plant densities are not recommended under drought conditions (Gardner and Gardner, 1983;Lyon et al., 2003). Higher plant densities increase ET during the vegetative period (Echarte et al., 2020), which could reduce soil water availability at the beginning of the critical period for kernel set. Then, when water is scarce, high plant densities could increase the likelihood of water deficiencies during the critical period for kernel set. It has been shown that low soil water supply https://doi.org/10.1016/j.fcr.2020.107844 Received 4 February 2020; Received in revised form 16 April 2020; Accepted 6 May 2020 during this period may constrain CGRcp (Andrade et al., 2002b;Echarte and Tollenaar., 2006) and grain yield (Calviño et al., 2003) and thus, may limit WUEg response to plant density.

The understanding of the eco-physiological processes underlying WUEg response to plant density is far for being complete, and the influence of increasing plant density on WUEg in water-limited environments is yet to be elucidated. To shed some light on the issue, this study i) quantified the response of maize WUEg and its components (grain yield, and ET) to plant density increments under contrasting water availability conditions and ii) evaluated underlying eco-physiological processes relevant to the responses of WUEg to plant density (i.e., T/ET ratio and CGRcp).

Maize crops were grown at Balcarce, Argentina (37°45S, 58°18W; elevation 130 m), during 2015-2016 (Season1) and 2016-2017 (Season 2). The soil was a complex of a fine mixed Typic Argiudoll and a fine thermic Petrocalcic Paleudoll (petrocalcic horizon at 170-190 cm), with a loam texture at the surface layer (0-25-cm depth), loam to clayloam at sub-surface layers (25-110-cm depth) and sandy-loam below 110-cm depth (C-horizon) with 5.4% topsoil organic matter. Field capacity was 3.6 mm cm -1 (at -33 kPa pressure) while the permanent wilting point (PWP) was 2 mm cm -1 (at -1500 kPa). The field capacity is a measure of soil ability to retain water after internal drainage has ended (Hillel, 1998) and estimates the upper limit of plant available water (Veihmeyer and Hendrickson, 1950). The permanent wilting point (PWP) is the soil water content below which the plant cannot recover turgidity (Hillel, 1998) and thus represents the lowest limit of plant available water (Veihmeyer and Hendrickson, 1950). Both traits were determined according to Richards and Weaver (1943). Experiments were conducted under conventional tillage and were fertilized with 30 kg P ha -1 at sowing and with 250 kg N ha -1 at V6 stage (Ritchie and Hanway, 1982). Weeds and insects were effectively controlled.

Maize hybrid DK 692 VT3P, a widely used hybrid across the Argentinean maize cropping area, was sown on 21 Oct in Season 1 and on 31 Oct in Season 2. Treatments included two water regimes (rainfed and irrigated) and three plant densities (4, 8 and 12 pl m -2 ). The treatments were arranged in a split-plot design with three replicates; irrigation treatments were assigned to the main plots and plant densities to the subplots. Subplots comprised six rows, 0.7 m apart and 12 m long. Four additional rows were included in between irrigation and rainfed treatments. In the irrigation treatments, drip irrigation was performed to maintain soil water availability above 50% of soil available water during the entire growing season (Doremboos and Kassam, 1979). Fig. 1 depicts moments of irrigation and amounts of water for the different treatments. Hand sowing was performed with two seeds per drop, which were thinned to the target plant densities at V2-3 (Ritchie and Hanway, 1982).

Silking date was recorded for each experimental unit as the date when 50% of the plants presented at least one emerged silk from the husks. Physiological maturity date was taken to occur when kernel weight (KW) was constant. Kernel weight was determined every 7 days during the filling period, by collecting 5 kernels from the central part of the ear row in 5 consecutive plants, in all the treatments. The date of PM was estimated by fitting a linear with plateau model (Jandel, 1992) to the relationship between KW and days after silking for each treatment in each season, following Echarte and Tollenaar. (2006).

Soil water content (SW) was measured with a neutron probe (Troxler Electronic Lab., Troxler 4300, NC, USA) in each experimental unit from emergence until PM. Neutron probe measurements in 20 cm increments between 10 and 170 (Season 1) or 190 cm (Season 2) were combined with gravimetric measurements between 0 and 10 cm depth. Differences in the total soil depth between seasons were due to different location of experiments. One access tube per experimental unit was placed midway between the two central rows and soil water content was measured every 7-15 days. Probe data were expressed in water content according to Suero and Travasso (1988).

Soil E was measured using micro-lysimeters following Hernández et al. (2015). Briefly, micro-lysimeters consisted of a plastic pipe (inside diameter 0.1 m, 0.15 m long with a wire mesh at the bottom) filled with non-disturbed soil samples taken from the inter-row. The micro-lysimeters were weighed and placed in the same spot from where the soil samples were taken; and they were weighed again after 48 h. Previous E measurements in the experimental site indicated that soil within the micro-lysimeter was representative of real evaporation for up to 48 h (Valenzuela, 2010) in agreement with other works (Boast and Robertson, 1982;Allen, 1990). Water loss from micro-lysimeters was not attributable to root activity (Villalobos and Fereres, 1990). Soil E measurements were performed twice within a period of 15-20 days, accounting for (i) E after irrigation and/or rainfall (i.e. humid period) and (ii) E at least 3 days after a rain event (i.e. dry period).

Shoot biomass was determined in 10 plants per subplot at around 15 days before and after silking and at PM. Samples were taken from the central rows of each subplot leaving borders of at least 1 m between successive harvests. Plants were separated into stem, leaves, ears and husks, oven-dried to constant weight (forced air at 65 °C) and weighed.

Crop evapotranspiration (ET, mm) was calculated by means of a soil water balance (Allen et al., 1998;Eq. ( 2)):

Where P is precipitation, ΔW is the change in soil water storage between two observation dates, D is drainage (i.e., the amount of water discharged outside the root zone), R is runoff and CR is capillary rise.

Neutron probe measurements showed no evidence of excess of water in the bottom layer of soil at any plant density or growing season; thus, deep percolation was considered unlikely and drainage, negligible. Soil water availability in the bottom soil layer (150-170 cm in Season 1 and 170-190 cm in Season 2) was below 65% in all measurements. Crop ET calculations assumed that i) precipitation was totally incorporated into the soil, ii) the application efficiency of supplemental irrigations was 100%, and iii) runoff and capillary rise were negligible. These assumptions were based on the fact that no slopes were evident in the experiment layout, no runoff was observed, groundwater level was below 10 m depth in this soil and measurements were performed in the whole soil profile up to the petrocalcic horizon. Seasonal ET was calculated by accumulating ET from emergence to PM. Water use efficiency for grain yield (WUEg) was estimated as the quotient between grain yield and seasonal crop ET. The response of WUEg to plant density increments above 4 plants m -2 (WUEgR) was estimated as [(WUEg (8 or 12) -WUEg (4) ) / WUEg (4) ] x 100, where WUEg (8 or 12) refers to WUEg at 8 or 12 plants m -2 , respectively and WUEg (4) refers to WUEg at 4 plants m -2 .

Where ΔW is the difference between weight of the micro-lysimeter at the beginning and at the end of the E measurement period, 150 mm is the length of the tube, Vs is soil volume, ρ w is water density (1.0 g cm -3 ) and 2 days is the time that the lysimeters were left in the field.

The quotient between E/ET 0 for each day of E measurement was used to estimate daily E as a function of ET 0 in-between E measurements. Daily E on a day with irrigation or rainfall was estimated using the closest E/ET 0 corresponding to a humid period (i.e., E measured after an irrigation or rain event); daily E on a day without irrigation or rainfall was estimated using the closest E/ET 0 corresponding to a dry period (i.e., E measured at least 3 days after an irrigation or rain event). Seasonal E was estimated by accumulating E from sowing to PM; and seasonal T was estimated as the difference between ET and E.

Percent photosynthetically active radiation interception (%iPAR) was calculated as [1-(I T /I 0 )] ×100, where I T is the incident light below the lowest level of green leaves and I 0 is the incident light at the top of the canopy. The values of I T and I 0 were obtained with a line quantum sensor (Cavadevices. BAR-RAD 100. Buenos Aires. Argentina). Measurements were performed in clear sky days around noon, from 14 days after emergence until physiological maturity every 7-10 days, following the method of Gallo and Daughtry (1986). Global radiation was transformed to PAR by multiplying it by 0.48 (Monteith, 1972). Absolute iPAR for each day of measurement was estimated as daily incident PAR x %iPAR; and values were interpolated and accumulated between measurements until PM to estimate accumulated iPAR during the season (i.e. seasonal iPAR).

Crop growth rate during the critical period for kernel set (CGRcp) was estimated as the quotient between accumulated shoot biomass and the duration of the period. The response of CGRcp to plant density increments above 4 plants m -2 (CGRcpR) was estimated as [(CGRcp (8 or 12) -CGRcp (4) ) / CGRcp (4) ] x 100, where CGRcp (8 or 12) refers to CGRcp at 8 or 12 plants m -2 , respectively and CGRcp (4) refers to CGRcp at 4 plants m -2 . Harvest index was estimated as grain yield divided by final shoot biomass.

paragraphs.title: Seasonal T/ET ratio and crop growth rate during the critical period for kernel set

div.text: Seasonal T/ET ratio increased with plant density in any season and under any water regime (Fig. 2a). Seasonal iPAR also increased with plant density and seasonal T/ET ratio was positively and closely related to seasonal iPAR across plant densities, water regimes and seasons (p < 0.05; Fig. 2b). In turn, seasonal E linearly decreased (E = -0.484 iPAR + 8.091; R 2 = 0.62) and seasonal T linearly increased (T = 0.585 iPAR -4.427; R 2 = 0.73) with increasing iPAR. Although in general, WUEg increased with seasonal iPAR, when water was scarce the trend was the opposite (Fig. 2c). In the same way, increments in seasonal T/ ET ratio contributed to explain WUEg responses to higher densities, except in the driest environment (i.e., rainfed treatment of Season 1; Fig. 2d).

Processes underlying the response of WUEg to plant density under contrasting water supply were further evaluated with special interest on (i) the ET partition towards productive water use during the season (i.e., T/ET ratio) and on (ii) the growth capacity during the critical period for kernel set (i.e., CGRcp).

Previous works have already demonstrated the importance of water supply during the critical period for kernel set on defining grain yield (e.g., Calviño et al., 2003). This work further elucidated the processes contributing to grain yield and WUEg responses to plant density under contrasting water supply. We demonstrated that CGRcp response to increments in plant density was largely influenced by water supply (Fig. 3b), and it accounted for 96% of the response of WUEg to plant density (Fig. 3c). Other traits influencing kernel set (e.g., silks emergence synchrony, Oury et al., 2016;reproductive plasticity, Ross et al., 2020) might also contribute to explain WUEg response to plant density under contrasting water supply.

This manuscript contributed to elucidate eco-physiological processes underlying WUEg response to plant density. We have shown that increasing plant density increased WUEg, except when water was limiting. Increasing plant density improved the ET partition towards productive water use (i.e., higher T/ET ratio) in accordance with increasing iPAR. However, increments in iPAR and in the T/ET ratio in environments limited by water during the critical period for kernel set failed to increase WUEg. We demonstrated that the response of the crop growth rate during the critical period for kernel set to increments in plant density (i) was influenced by water supply during this period and (ii) it greatly (96%) contributed to explain WUEg response to plant density increments under contrasting water supplies.
